metadata.titleEn: Data set of total mercury in leaves of common tree species in the East and south of Qinghai Tibet Plateau (2008)
metadata.description: This dataset includes the concentrations and spatial pattern of mercury (Hg) in the foliage of the local tree species over the easteran and the southern Tibetan Plateau. Fifty-three leaf samples were collected, and cold vapor atomic fluorescence spectrophotometry (CVAFS) was used to analyse the Hg contents. The limit of detection (LOD) for this method is 1.8 ng/g. The standard reference material, foliage GB GSW-11, which is supplied by National Institute of Metrology P.R.China, was also analyzed for assessing the accuracy of this method, and the recoveries of this method were 94.6%±9.7%. This dataset will provide the informations of foliage absoprtion to Hg over the Tibetan Plateau.
metadata.instructions: In .excel format, can be opened and analysed in Microsoft EXCEL software.

authorList.unitEn: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research,Chinese Academy of Sciences

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used for measuring total mercury concentration in tree leaves in the eastern and southern Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: 53 locations, atomic fluorescence, detection limit 1.8 ng/g, standard leaf samples GB GSW-11, experimental recovery rate 94.6%±9.7%

Quantification.Question: What is the detection limit used for measuring total mercury concentration in the tree leaves dataset?

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of measuring total mercury concentration in tree leaves in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The factors include the need for accurate sampling across a diverse geographical area, variability in tree species common to the eastern and southern parts of the Tibetan Plateau, and ensuring precise measurement using atomic fluorescence with a detection limit of 1.8 ng/g. Additionally, maintaining high experimental recovery rates, such as 94.6%±9.7% using standard leaf samples as reference material, is essential.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using atomic fluorescence method for measuring total mercury concentration in tree leaves on the reliability and accuracy of atmospheric mercury absorption data for vegetation in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using the atomic fluorescence method, which has a detection limit of 1.8 ng/g and an experimental recovery rate of 94.6%±9.7%, could lead to high reliability and accuracy in measuring total mercury concentration in tree leaves. This can improve the quality of reference datasets for evaluating the impact of transboundary air pollutants from South Asia on the Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting leaf samples and measuring total mercury concentration in common tree species across the eastern and southern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include obtaining reference data for evaluating how vegetation in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau absorbs atmospheric mercury, which can be used to assess the impact of transboundary atmospheric pollution from South Asia on the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to measure and ensure the accuracy of total mercury concentration in tree leaves within datasets related to the eastern and southern Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To measure and ensure accuracy of total mercury concentration in tree leaves, atomic fluorescence spectrometry was utilized with a detection limit of 1.8 ng/g. Standard reference material, specifically GB GSW-11, was used to validate the experimental procedure, resulting in a recovery rate of 94.6%±9.7%.
